update.description:
Part of issue #853 - 8th [most voted](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues?status=new&status=open) issue in Gazebo :smile: (it only takes 4 votes to get there....)

Adds an option to view link frames, both from the toolbar (applies to all models at once) and from the right-click menu (all links in one model).

The frame for the currently selected link shows up opaque. Let me know if you think it is too transparent when not selected - I wanted it not to be too crowded and to have a high contrast from the selected one.

Note: not available within the Model Editor yet.

I guess there are no unexpected failures in [homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/300/#showFailuresLink)

[Trusty GPU is happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/218/) with 100% function test [coverage](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/218/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64_gazebo_gazebo_rendering/LinkFrameVisual_cc.html) for the new test. 

![linkFrames1.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4161311822-linkFrames1.png)

![linkFrame2.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3607242089-linkFrame2.png)

![linkFrame3.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4029000073-linkFrame3.png)
update.title: Link frame visual

content.raw: Thanks, I see clearly now (I was using cubes and cans before).
content.html: Thanks, I see clearly now (I was using cubes and cans before).

content.raw: If you select a link, its frame should look solid. For example, insert the double pendulum and on the left panel select `upper_link`. Make sure the model is transparent. Only the frame for that link should look solid.
content.html: If you select a link, its frame should look solid. For example, insert the double pendulum and on the left panel select upper_link. Make sure the model is transparent. Only the frame for that link should look solid.

content.raw: On my machine the link frames are always transparent, but they look solid on some of the pictures here. Is this OK?
content.html: On my machine the link frames are always transparent, but they look solid on some of the pictures here. Is this OK?

content.raw: ok I see. The movable text option sounds good when we eventually start adding more frame visuals. I am ok with the link frame visualization as it is now
content.html: ok I see. The movable text option sounds good when we eventually start adding more frame visuals. I am ok with the link frame visualization as it is now

content.raw:
Yeah, this is indeed tough.  Currently, the joint visual seems different enough from the link visual because the joint visual has arrows on each axis, and yellow arrows communicating joint type. The link indicator doesn't have arrows. So far so good. Once we add model, collision, visual frames, we'll have a bigger problem. 

Changing the color would differentiate between the types, but I worry that users would still need to go look up what the different colors mean. Same for cylinder size. We'd be better off using movable text (type?) to add a tiny V, C, L, etc. above each marker to indicate "visual", "collision", etc. Does that make sense?

This is also a case where I think we need to rely on the users to keep track of what they toggled. 

I'm definitely open to other suggestions, I just can't think of anything elegant.
content.html:
Yeah, this is indeed tough. Currently, the joint visual seems different enough from the link visual because the joint visual has arrows on each axis, and yellow arrows communicating joint type. The link indicator doesn't have arrows. So far so good. Once we add model, collision, visual frames, we'll have a bigger problem.

Changing the color would differentiate between the types, but I worry that users would still need to go look up what the different colors mean. Same for cylinder size. We'd be better off using movable text (type?) to add a tiny V, C, L, etc. above each marker to indicate "visual", "collision", etc. Does that make sense?

This is also a case where I think we need to rely on the users to keep track of what they toggled.

I'm definitely open to other suggestions, I just can't think of anything elegant.

content.raw: Oops sorry, forgot about this one, here you are b4563fd
content.html: Oops sorry, forgot about this one, here you are b4563fd

content.raw:
this should do it

~~~
return math::equal(this->GetTransparency(), dPtr->highlightedTransp);
~~~
content.html:
this should do it
